commit_message:
Query and cancel ongoing live migrations

This spec proposes a new API to allow an operator to query and
cancel ongoing live migrations.

APIImpact

blueprint refresh-abort-live-migration

Change-Id: Ieff68ceec5c59ea1190c1a7e7f8b1d47188565df
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/49/179149/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================== Provide a way to stop an in-progress live-migration =================================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: TBC: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/example After starting live migration, it may be that an operator wishes to cancel the migration before it finishes. Currently this requires intervention at the hypervisor level. This spec proposes a new nova command for stopping an in-progress live migration. Problem description =================== It may be that an operator decides, after starting a live migration, that they would like to cancel it. Effectively this would mean rolling-back any partial migration that has happened and leaving the instance on the source node. It may be that the migration is taking too long, or some operational problem is discovered with the target node. As the set of operations that can be performed on an instance during live migration is restricted (only delete is currently allowed), it may be that an instance owner has requested that their instance be made available urgently. Currently aborting a live migration requires intervention at the hypervisor level then waiting for Nova to rediscover the correct state for the instance during its periodic tasks. Use Cases ---------- As an operator of an OpenStack cloud, I would like the ability to stop and roll back an ongoing live migration. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== A new API method for cancelling an ongoing live migration. Alternatives ------------ The alternative is not doing this, leaving it up to operators to roll up their sleeves and get to work on the hypervisor. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- * Stop an in-progress live migration `POST /servers/{server_id}/action` specify the `os-migrateLive-cancel` action in the request body:: { "os-migrateLive-cancel": null } Normal http response code: `202 Accepted` No response body is needed Expected error http response code: `409 Conflict` - instance is not currently in task_state.MIGRATING Policy: This does not need a separate policy control. It can be called by anyone who could have started the live migration, so can inherit that action's policy. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Rolling back a live migration should be very quick, as the source host is still active until the migration finishes. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers who have tooling around live migration may want to rewrite. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Matthew Gilliard (irc: gilliard) Work Items ---------- * API microversion increment * Implementation in compute manager. * Implementation in each virt driver. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Unit and Functional tests in Nova * Tempest tests Currently the aiopcpu jobs can test live migration. I expect the devstack setup used by those tests to be able to complete a live migration very quickly, so it may be necessary to use a fake virt driver to simulate a live migration slow enough that cancelling it reliably is possible. Ideally we would use a live migration which never completes. If this is not feasible in tempest then we are limited to in-tree unit and functional tests in Nova. Documentation Impact ==================== New API needs to be documented: * Compute API extensions documentation. http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html * nova.compute.api documentation http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/api/nova.compute.api.html References ========== Some details of how this can be done with libvirt: https://www.redhat.com/archives/libvirt-users/2014-January/msg00008.html History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Liberty - Introduced

commit_message:
Move puppet-lint gate to devstack-centos7

The main reason is to move away from the bare nodes, since -infra will
be retiring in the future.  Additionally, we move into centos7 to
avoid the hurt of other projects using devstack-trusty.

Since we are installing puppet from gems, we don't need to rely on the
OS as much. However, if we want to add a devstack-trusty node in the
future, we now can easily.

Change-Id: Ia73c6fd70971a704178d4b5f93502ceac0b85a92
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add branch logic check for puppet-unit experimental job

We would like to continue to keep using one single job to run Puppet
unit tests, whatever branch we are running.

For history, Puppet modules have a specific matrix of Puppet versions
support:
 +------------------------------------------+
 |        Puppet versions support matrix    |
 +------------------------------------------+
 | puppet | icehouse | juno | kilo | master |
 +------------------------------------------+
 | 3.x    |   yes    | yes  | yes  | yes    |
 | 4.0    |   no     | no   | yes  | yes    |
 | latest |   no     | no   | no   | yes    |
 +------------------------------------------+

This patch aims to keep the logic we have in Zuul layout for regular
(that will be dropped in near future) which take care of branches & what
to run, but in Jenkins jobs itself by using ZUUL_BRANCH.

That way, we have one single experimental job able to detect what we
actually need to run and fail in consequence of a failing test for a
specific version.

This patch also adds debug messages at the end of the job so we can
easily know what is failing or not, regarding Puppet versions.

Change-Id: I39e1ce3a3daf31072930cfb612ff052b0301dd48
Co-Authored-By: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/27/220527/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ "$ZUUL_BRANCH" = "stable/kilo" ]; then GEMS+=" 4.0" elif [ "$ZUUL_BRANCH" = "master" ]; then GEMS+=" 4.0 latest" fi for PUPPET_VERSION in $GEMS; do
deleted_lines: for PUPPET_VERSION in {puppet_unit_version}; do puppet_unit_version: '3.3 3.4 3.6 3.7 3.8 4.0 latest'

commit_message:
hardware: improve parse_cpu_spec to handle exclusion range

This commit improves method parse_cpu_spec to handle exclusion
range. Now rule like: ^0-1 or 0-5, ^2-5 will work.

Change-Id: I437cf54bb1d67d6c11eff11651c4e6e63a9f384b

commit_message:
Move all tests to different folders

Moved all unit and functional tests from tests folder
to tests/unit and tests/functional folders respectively

Partially implements: blueprint ceilometer-functional-tests

Change-Id: I02ba4f2dbd5efddddf30a5affc9af5a6a3dc3802

commit_message:

commit_message:
Force utf8 encoding on subunit attachments output

On certain environments if the locale is set to ASCII when printing an
attachment things will explode because it's potentially trying to use
unicode chars outside of ASCII. This commit forces the attachment
output to be unicode encoded to avoid this issue.

Change-Id: I79ff7482ec3b1fd3ce83b8acf3137119b3db39a9
Closes-Bug: #1501415

This patch adds the ISCSITargetUtils class,

commit_message:
remove log message when process notification

message may contain some sensitive information, for example, auth
token. This patch removes log entire message in network.notications

Change-Id: I7e5f37668ab2a8bcf191ad886ac54352727272f7
Closes-Bug: #1433004
(cherry picked from commit fd2a66f9a3a2d6612a05a3df258c3ce46bb154f2)

commit_message:
doa does not work with mysql

recent change to specify db user model and it's key
are not compliant with mysql

This change modifies the character limit to be 255 instead of 256,
which is compliant with mysql.

Change-Id: I85f984c690297003d0e6d696f3103ad5fcf34045
Closes-bug: #1499856

commit_message:
Fix database schema for mysql and switch the gate to testing it

MySQL can't use TEXT fields for primary keys. This change switches all them
to VARCHAR(255). This change should not be breaking for SQLite, as it
does not distinguish between these two data types.

README is updated with up-to-date information about the connection option.

Change-Id: I0153855c1827b55067a7c04310bfad7eb71f35fe
Closes-Bug: #1501746

added_lines: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE chapter [ <!ENTITY % common_project SYSTEM "../wadls/common_project.ent"> %common_project; ]> <chapter xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns:linkend="http://www.w3.org/1999/linkend" xmlns:xref="http://www.w3.org/1999/xref" xmlns:wadl="http://wadl.dev.java.net/2009/02" version="5.0-extension RackBook-2.0" xml:id="share-api-v2-experimental" role="api-reference"> <title>Shared File System API v2 (EXPERIMENTAL)</title> <para> This chapter provides information about experimental part of Shared File System API. This part of API can be changed without keeping backward compatibility and can be removed in future releases. </para> <section xml:id="share-versions"> <title>API versions</title> <para> Lists information for all Shared File System API versions. </para> </section> </chapter>

commit_message:
Add production-use data for Juno

Since the project information will include supported releases,
add the data for ops:production-use for Juno.

Data source:
http://superuser.openstack.org/articles/openstack-user-survey-insights-november-2014

Change-Id: Iff8df2bacc507a8dfc6d81c2e425769190095597
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ops-tags-team refs/changes/61/223461/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: { "Compute service (Nova)": { "status": "93%" }, "Object Storage service (Swift)": { "status": "49%" }, "Image service (Glance)": { "status": "85%" }, "Identity service (Keystone)": { "status": "90%" }, "Dashboard (Horizon)": { "status": "81%" }, "Networking service (Neutron)": { "status": "68%" }, "Block Storage service (Cinder)": { "status": "73%" }, "Telemetry service (Ceilometer)": { "status": "33%" }, "Orchestration service (Heat)": { "status": "32%" }, "Database service (Trove)": { "status": "9%" }, "Data Processing service (Sahara)": { "status": "0%" }, "Bare Metal service (Ironic)": { "status": "5%" }, "Message service (Zaqar)": { "status": "0%" }, "Key Management service (Barbican)": { "status": "0%" }, "DNS service (Designate)": { "status": "0%" } }

Support PowerVM attribute 'powervm:processor_compatibility'.

Support PowerVM extra spec attribute 'powervm:processor_compatibility
during the conversion of flavor from nova format to pypowervm format.

commit_message:
Update glance_store configuration to use Keystone v3

Swift was previously hard-coded to use v2.0 of Keystone's API but as of
Ifb7c9be805689e938ff0e99a18fa220993862001 it can now be configured to
use v3. It also adds two new configuration options so swiftclient can
appropriately authenticate before talking to Swift.

New configurable options:
 - glance_swift_store_auth_version
   This is the Keystone API auth version to use. The previous default
   was 2, but this patch changes it to 3.

 - glance_swift_store_user_domain
   This is the Domain ID for the user used to authenticate to Swift.

 - glance_swift_store_project_domain
   This is the Domain ID for the project used to authenticate to Swift.

DocImpact
UpgradeImpact
Closes-bug: 1479131
Change-Id: I35684d6025eea3a884a0ec7cd1d8f288f70ecead
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/43/206743/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: user_domain_id = default project_domain_id = default swift_store_auth_version = 3

commit_message:
liberty: release 2.30.1 for python-novaclient

This contains the fix for bug 1501435 so that legacy block device
mapping requests work in liberty (with openstackclient).

This the change log since 2.30.0:

3424bc6 Always send volume_id when booting with legacy bdm
0afb131 Update .gitreview for stable/liberty

Related-Bug: #1501435

commit_message:
Add subca functionality to the dogtag plugin

The Dogtag CA plugin has been modified to support
subordinate CAs.  This includes updating the list of
CAs read from the CA when the the ca list is refreshed.

Unit tests for the Dogtag CA have been updated, and functional
tests have been added for the Dogtag CA for subca creation.

Also added some exceptions to convey issues in subca creation
and deletion.

Partially-Implements: blueprint add-cas
Change-Id: I1766cb4a2069ea56d386067c9aa2811a50410a9d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/93/227893/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import datetime subcas_available = True try: import pki.authority as authority import pki.feature as feature except ImportError: subcas_available = False help=u._('List of automatically approved enrollment profiles')), cfg.StrOpt('ca_expiration_data_path', help=u._('Path to the CA expiration tracking file')), cfg.StrOpt('ca_expiration_time', default=cm.CA_INFO_DEFAULT_EXPIRATION_DAYS, help=u._('Time in days for CA entries to expire')), cfg.StrOpt('ca_host_aid_path', help=u._('Path to the CA host ID tracking file')) self._expiration = None self._expiration_delta = conf.dogtag_plugin.ca_expiration_time self._expiration_data_path = conf.dogtag_plugin.ca_expiration_data_path if not os.path.isfile(self._expiration_data_path): self.expiration = datetime.datetime.utcnow() global subcas_available subcas_available = self._check_subcas(connection) if subcas_available: self.authority_client = authority.AuthorityClient(connection) @property def expiration(self): if self._expiration is None: with open(self._expiration_data_path) as expiration_fh: self._expiration = datetime.datetime.strptime( expiration_fh.read(), "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%f" ) return self._expiration @expiration.setter def expiration(self, val): with open(self._expiration_data_path, 'w') as expiration_fh: expiration_fh.write(val.strftime("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%f")) self._expiration = val @property def host_aid(self): if self._host_aid is None: with open(self._host_aid_path) as host_aid_fh: self._host_aid = host_aid_fh.read() return self._host_aid @host_aid.setter def host_aid(self, val): with open(self._host_aid_path, 'w') as host_aid_fh: host_aid_fh.write(val) self._host_aid = val def _check_subcas(self, connection): """Check if subca feature is available SubCA creation must be supported in both the Dogtag client as well as on the back-end server. Moreover, it must be enabled on the backend server. This method sets the subcas_available global variable. :return: True/False """ global subcas_available if subcas_available: # subcas are supported in the Dogtag client try: feature_client = feature.FeatureClient(connection) authority_feature = feature_client.get_feature("authority") if authority_feature.enabled: # subcas supported on the Dogtag server return True except (request_exceptions.HTTPError, pki.ResourceNotFoundException): return False return False ca_id = barbican_meta_dto.plugin_ca_id or self.get_default_ca_name() if profile_id in self.auto_approved_profiles: if ca_id == self.get_default_ca_name(): results = self.certclient.enroll_cert(profile_id, inputs) else: results = self.certclient.enroll_cert( profile_id, inputs, ca_id) if ca_id == self.get_default_ca_name(): results = self.certclient.submit_enrollment_request(request) else: results = self.certclient.submit_enrollment_request( request, ca_id) def supports_create_ca(self): """Returns if this plugin and the backend CA supports subCAs :return: True/False """ return subcas_available def create_ca(self, ca_create_dto): """Creates a subordinate CA upon request :param ca_create_dto: Data transfer object :class:`CACreateDTO` containing data required to generate a subordinate CA. This data includes the subject DN of the new CA signing certificate, a name for the new CA and a reference to the CA that will issue the new subordinate CA's signing certificate, :return: ca_info: Dictionary containing the data needed to create a models.CertificateAuthority object """ if not subcas_available: raise exception.SubCAsNotSupported( "Subordinate CAs are not supported by this Dogtag CA") parent_ca_id = self._get_correct_ca_id(ca_create_dto.parent_ca_id) ca_data = authority.AuthorityData( dn=ca_create_dto.subject_dn, parent_aid=parent_ca_id, description=ca_create_dto.name) new_ca_data = self.authority_client.create_ca(ca_data) cert = self.authority_client.get_cert(new_ca_data.aid, "PEM") chain = self.authority_client.get_chain(new_ca_data.aid, "PEM") return { cm.INFO_NAME: new_ca_data.description, cm.INFO_CA_SIGNING_CERT: cert, cm.INFO_EXPIRATION: self.expiration, cm.INFO_INTERMEDIATES: chain, cm.PLUGIN_CA_ID: new_ca_data.aid } def _get_correct_ca_id(self, plugin_ca_id): """Returns the correct authority id When the Dogtag plugin updates its CA list, any subcas will have a plugin_ca_id that matches the authority_id (aid) as returned from the backend CA. For migration purposes, though, ie. migrating from a non-subca environment to a subca one, we want the host CA to keep the same plugin_ca_id (which is the default_ca_name) so that no disruption occurs. Therefore, we need to store the host CA's authority ID (in get_ca_info) and return it here instead. """ if plugin_ca_id == self.get_default_ca_name(): return self.host_aid else: return plugin_ca_id def delete_ca(self, ca_id): """Deletes a subordinate CA In the Dogtag back-end, the CA is not deleted. Rather, it is disabled. :param ca_id: id for the CA as specified by the plugin :return: None """ if not subcas_available: raise exception.SubCAsNotSupported( "Subordinate CAs are not supported by this Dogtag CA") self.authority_client.disable_ca(ca_id) def get_ca_info(self): if not subcas_available: return super(DogtagCAPlugin, self).get_ca_info() self.expiration = (datetime.datetime.utcnow() + datetime.timedelta( days=self._expiration_delta)) ret = {} cas = self.authority_client.list_cas() for ca_data in cas.ca_list: if not ca_data.enabled: continue cert = self.authority_client.get_cert(ca_data.aid, "PEM") chain = self.authority_client.get_chain(ca_data.aid, "PEM") ca_info = { cm.INFO_NAME: ca_data.description, cm.INFO_CA_SIGNING_CERT: cert, cm.INFO_INTERMEDIATES: chain, cm.INFO_EXPIRATION: self.expiration } # handle the migration case. The top level CA should continue # to work as before if ca_data.is_host_authority: ret[self.get_default_ca_name()] = ca_info self.host_aid = ca_data.aid else: ret[ca_data.aid] = ca_info return ret
deleted_lines: help=u._('List of automatically approved enrollment profiles')) if profile_id in self.auto_approved_profiles: results = self.certclient.enroll_cert(profile_id, inputs) results = self.certclient.submit_enrollment_request(request)

commit_message:
Revert "Add all tenants search opt to del instnce by name"

This reverts commit a0481e1c8008935d34e8f6e2cf896723b5e36f0a.

While its nice to allow admin users to delete by name any VM,
it now stops regular users from deleting by name.

Change-Id: Ia2482c3db3b16817863ed490056ea362c290194f

commit_message:
Add reno for release notes

reno is a new tool for managing release notes using text files inside
the repository. We will need to add it to the test-requirements.txt file
so the sphinx integration can be used to publish release notes in the
development documentation builds.

Change-Id: Ibb2a08e9513123486ca58188ec097b7cd00c0d7f
(cherry picked from commit fed1805227fb10ec6a11fe07f397c82bc7eaa3a7)

commit_message:
Fix some tab name error bugs in 'dashboard_databases.rst'

The 'Databases' tab should be 'Database', the 'Database Instances' tab
should be 'Instances', and the 'Database Backups' should be 'Backups'.

Change-Id: I8bfcbe6679c82c056e02b26ddddbb9c28e6a6825
Closes-bug: #1500316

subject: Fix file checksum function in for python 3.4
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-28 20:24:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/commit/8d402237d19d1b015432cc52bde8ce156192a41f', 'message': "Fix file checksum function in for python 3.4

The file_checksum function in tripleoclient/utils.py resulted in an
infinite loop in py34 due to the fact that that function was expecting
an empty character to finish the iteration. This is no longer the case
in py34. So instead, we now iterate the file until it can no longer read
anything. Even though it's more verbose; this works for both python 2.7
and 3.4.

Change-Id: I4849182992cac1209431a2147a83c9167d6a8af2

commit_message:
Fix file checksum function in for python 3.4

The file_checksum function in tripleoclient/utils.py resulted in an
infinite loop in py34 due to the fact that that function was expecting
an empty character to finish the iteration. This is no longer the case
in py34. So instead, we now iterate the file until it can no longer read
anything. Even though it's more verbose; this works for both python 2.7
and 3.4.

Change-Id: I4849182992cac1209431a2147a83c9167d6a8af2
Closes-Bug: #1500592

commit_message:
Clarify documentation about scope

This change adds a little more context about how keystone deals with
authorization and scope. Specifically for unscoped, domain-scoped, and
project-scoped tokens.

Change-Id: I4ced9aa8ebe8b4a06830f7126b382d8b5977c0e2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/92/224792/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: An authorization scope, including either a ``project``, ``domain``, or ``unscoped``, can be optionally specified as part of the request. If both a ``domain`` and a ``project`` are specified, an HTTP 400 Bad Request will be returned, as a token cannot be simultaneously scoped to both a ``project`` and ``domain``. Unscoped '''''''' Unscoped token request bodies may, or may not, contain a ``scope``. If an unscoped token request contains ``scope`` and it is set to ``unscoped``, it is considered an explicit unscoped token request. Which will return an unscoped response without any authorization. :: { "auth": { "identity": { "methods": [ "password" ], "password": { "user": { "id": "0ca8f6", "password": "secretsecret" } } }, "scope": "unscoped" } } Unscoped requests have the ability to return project-scoped responses if the user making the request has the ``default_project_id`` set to an existing project on their user reference, and they have an assignment to the project. In that case, it would be possible for a user to get a project-scoped token response without explicitly asking for project scope. This is considered the preferred authorization scope if ``scope`` is not provided in the request. :: { "auth": { "identity": { "methods": [ "password" ], "password": { "user": { "id": "0ca8f6", "password": "secretsecret" } } } } } If there is no default project defined, then a token will be issued without an explicit scope of authorization. Which is the same behavior ask asking for an explicit unscoped token. *New in version 3.1* Additionally, if the user's default project is invalid, a token will be issued without an explicit scope of authorization. *New in version 3.4* A user may explicitly request an unscoped token by setting the "scope" value of the token request to the string "unscoped." This will behave the same as a token request with no scope, where the user has no default project defined. Domain Scope '''''''''''' A ``domain`` scope may be specified by either the domain's ``id`` or ``name`` with equivalent results. Example request specifying a domain by ``id``: :: { "auth": { "identity": { "methods": [ "password" ], "password": { "user": { "id": "0ca8f6", "password": "secretsecret" } } }, "scope": { "domain": { "id": "1789d1" } } } } Example request specifying a domain by ``name``: :: { "auth": { "identity": { "methods": [ "password" ], "password": { "user": { "id": "0ca8f6", "password": "secretsecret" } } }, "scope": { "domain": { "name": "example.com" } } } } Project Scope '''''''''''''sufficient to uniquely identify a ``project`` across a deployment. Example request:
deleted_lines: An authorization scope, including either a ``project`` or ``domain``, can be optionally specified as part of the request. If both a ``domain`` and a ``project`` are specified, an HTTP 400 Bad Request will be returned, as a token cannot be simultaneously scoped to both a ``project`` and ``domain``.sufficient to uniquely identify a ``project``. Example request:A ``domain`` scope may be specified by either the domain's ``id`` or ``name`` with equivalent results. Example request specifying a domain by ``id``: :: { "auth": { "identity": { "methods": [ "password" ], "password": { "user": { "id": "0ca8f6", "password": "secretsecret" } } }, "scope": { "domain": { "id": "1789d1" } } } } Example request specifying a domain by ``name``: :: { "auth": { "identity": { "methods": [ "password" ], "password": { "user": { "id": "0ca8f6", "password": "secretsecret" } } }, "scope": { "domain": { "name": "example.com" } } } } If neither a ``project`` nor a ``domain`` is provided for ``scope``, and the authenticating ``user`` has a defined default project (the user's ``default_project_id`` attribute), then this will be treated as the preferred authorization scope. If there is no default project defined, then a token will be issued without an explicit scope of authorization. *New in version 3.1* Additionally, if the user's default project is invalid, a token will be issued without an explicit scope of authorization. *New in version 3.4* A user may explicitly request an unscoped token by setting the "scope" value of the token request to the string "unscoped." This will behave the same as a token request with no scope, where the user has no default project defined.

commit_message:
DNM: performance test: 100 users/tenants

Do not merge.
This patch benchmarks the creation of 100 users and 100 tenants with
role assignment.

We would like to see how much time we need to create the resources and
how much time the second puppet run will take.

Change-Id: Ie4fafe8c39f3a644741e354a63e8113adb7ade16
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/09/225009/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Add support for backport-potential commit flag
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-21 12:56:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/73e21a90f829b573406a30f601c44101c8f527e5', 'message': 'Add support for backport-potential commit flag

This commit aims to add support to handle a new commit flag :
backport-potential.

When backport-potential flag is present in a commit message, when the
actual commit is merged, the CI will automatically submit a review to
backport the patch to previous releases.

Example of commit message on project X

Fix bug X in Y

A longer descriptions here. The same bug was present in both icehouse
and havana releases.

Closes-bug: #4242
backport-potential: icehouse havana

Once merged, two new reviews will be submitted in project X on branch
stable/icehouse and stable/havana

Change-Id: I2fac289a80f12d98b67af769e2dd251171dd4050
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-04-22 08:31:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/592697273b430d3f56b401ac3e86d07edc2fcde3', 'message': 'Add support for backport-potential commit flag

This commit aims to add support to handle a new commit flag :
backport-potential.

When backport-potential flag is present in a commit message, when the
actual commit is merged, the CI will automatically submit a review to
backport the patch to previous releases.

Example of commit message on project X

Fix bug X in Y

A longer descriptions here. The same bug was present in both icehouse
and havana releases.

Closes-bug: #4242
backport-potential: icehouse havana

Once merged, two new reviews will be submitted in project X on branch
stable/icehouse and stable/havana

Note: A user can specify a full git path like dev/X if a single word is

commit_message:
Add support for backport-potential commit flag

This commit aims to add support to handle a new commit flag :
backport-potential.

When backport-potential flag is present in a commit message, when the
actual commit is merged, the CI will automatically submit a review to
backport the patch to previous releases.

Example of commit message on project X

Fix bug X in Y

A longer descriptions here. The same bug was present in both icehouse
and havana releases.

Closes-bug: #4242
backport-potential: icehouse havana

Once merged, two new reviews will be submitted in project X on branch
stable/icehouse and stable/havana

Note: A user can specify a full git path like dev/X if a single word is
passed in backport-potential it will then be assumed stable/X

Change-Id: I2fac289a80f12d98b67af769e2dd251171dd4050

added_lines: #!/bin/bash -xe # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. OWN_PROJECT=$1 if [ -z "$OWN_PROJECT" ] ; then echo "usage: $0 project" exit 1 fi if [ -z "$ZUUL_REF" ] ; then echo "No ZUUL_REF set, exiting." exit 1 fi # WIP (spredzy) : Needs to be reworked. # Purpose of this function is to remove the 'backport-potential:' # flag when doing the cherry-pick to avoid dependency cycle. # # Original Commit Message (on master) # # Fix bug #4242 # # backport-potential: icehouse havana # Change-Id: XXXXXXXXX # # Replace Commit Message (on stable/icehouse) # # Fix bug #4242 # # Change-Id: XXXXXXXXX # (cherry picked from commit XXXXXX) # function remove_cherry_picks_flag_from_commit_msg { commitMsg="" rec=0 while read line ; do if echo $line | grep -q 'commitMessage:'; then rec=1 fi if echo $line | grep -q 'createdOn:'; then break fi if [[ $rec -eq 1 ]] ; then commitMsg="${commitMsg}\n${line}" fi done < <(echo $1) echo $commitMsg | sed 's/commitMessage: \(.*\)/\1/' } PROJECT_DIR=$(basename $PROJECT) rm -rf $PROJECT_DIR git clone ssh://$USERNAME@review.openstack.org:29418/$PROJECT.git pushd $PROJECT_DIR change_info=$(ssh -p 29418 $USERNAME@review.openstack.org gerrit query --current-patch-set status:open project:$PROJECT topic:$TOPIC owner:$USERNAME branch:$BRANCH) BACKPORTS_TO=`cat $change_info | grep 'backport-potential:' | sed 's/\s*backport-potential:\(.*\)/\1/'` if [ -n "BACKPORTS_TO" ] ; then for release in $BACKPORTS_TO; do if git branch -a | grep -q "^ remotes/origin/stable/$release$" ; then BRANCH="stable/$release" git checkout -B ${BRANCH} -t origin/${BRANCH} # Need to set the git config in each repo as we shouldn't # set it globally for the Jenkins user on the slaves. git config user.name "OpenStack Proposal Bot" git config user.email "openstack-infra@lists.openstack.org" git config gitreview.username "proposal-bot" # Do error checking manually to continue with the next project # in case of failures like a broken .gitreview file. set +e git review -s RET=$? set -e popd if [ "$RET" -ne "0" ] ; then ALL_SUCCESS=1 echo "Error in git review -s: Ignoring $PROJECT" continue fi pushd $PROJECT_DIR if ! git diff --stat --exit-code HEAD ; then git cherry-pick -x $ZUUL_REF git_args="-a -F-" ### GET ORIGINAL COMMIT MSG WITHOUT THE CHERRY-PICKS FLAG COMMIT_MSG=`remove_cherry_picks_flag_from_commit_msg $change_info` git commit $git_args <<EOF $COMMIT_MSG EOF # Do error checking manually to ignore one class of failure. set +e OUTPUT=$(git review -t $TOPIC $BRANCH) RET=$? [[ "$RET" -eq "0" || "$OUTPUT" =~ "no new changes" || "$OUTPUT" =~ "no changes made" ]] SUCCESS=$? [[ "$SUCCESS" -eq "0" && "$ALL_SUCCESS" -eq "0" ]] ALL_SUCCESS=$? set -e fi fi done fi popd exit $ALL_SUCCESS

It's possible to create multiple security groups with the same name,

The solution is to use the group id instead of group name in the form.

This only works with Neutron, because Nova-Network not only requires the

Change-Id: I83587e15a8c18d64a29fd1083e786a73162b19f9

commit_message:
Use security group id not name in the create instance dialog

It's possible to create multiple security groups with the same name,
and then launching an instance will error with "Error: Multiple
security_group matches found for name 'foo', use an ID to be more specific."

The solution is to use the group id instead of group name in the form.

This only works with Neutron, because Nova-Network not only requires the
groups to be passed by name, but also passes them by name internally in
several places.

Change-Id: I83587e15a8c18d64a29fd1083e786a73162b19f9
Partial-bug: #1203413
(cherry picked from commit 5562694b7c81821820a846dd76471f66d8a47c12)

commit_message:
Add propose-backports jobs to openstack/puppet-*

Add the feature backport-potential to a module underneath
openstack/puppet-* scope. Once the behavior will be validated
by the community apply this hook on every module of the PuppetOpenstack
scope.

Change-Id: Idb793b6acba187c610d74750eecb35e434da785c

Update README.md

This change updates the README to include more useful information about
fuel-library as an open source project.

Change-Id: Ie31cc684307331cf3d51a56e3621101b1edd9505
Closes-Bug: #1500069
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/02/228602/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # fuel-library -------------- ## Table of Contents 1. [Overview - What is the fuel-library?](#overview) 2. [Structure - What is in the fuel-library?](#structure) 3. [Granular Deployment - What is the granular deployment for Fuel?](#granular-deployment) 4. [Upstream Modules - How to work with librarian.](#upstream-modules) 5. [Testing - How to run fuel-library tests.](#testing) ## Overview -------- The fuel-library is collection of Puppet modules and related code used by Fuel to deploy OpenStack environments. ## Structure --------- ### Basic Repository Layout ``` fuel-library ├── CHANGELOG ├── LICENSE ├── README.md ├── debian ├── deployment ├── files ├── specs ├── tests └── utils ``` ### root The root level contains important repository documentation and license information. ### debian/ This folder contains the required information to create fuel-library debian packages. ### deployment/ This folder contains the fuel-library Puppet code, the Puppetfile for upstream modules, and scripts to manage modules with [librarian-puppet-simple](https://github.com/bodepd/librarian-puppet-simple). ### files/ This folder contains scripts and configuration files that are used when creating the packages for fuel-library. ### specs/ This folder contains our rpm spec file for fuel-library rpm packages. ### tests/ This folder contains our testing scripts for the fuel-library. ### utils/ This folder contains scripts that are useful when doing development on fuel-library ## Granular Deployment ---------------------- TODO. ## Upstream Modules ------------------- In order to be able to pull in upstream modules for use by the fuel-library, the deployment folder contains a Puppetfile for use with [librarian-puppet-simple](https://github.com/bodepd/librarian-puppet-simple). Upstream modules should be used whenever possible. For additional details on the process for working with upstream modules, please read the [Fuel library for Puppet manifests](https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Fuel/How_to_contribute#Fuel_library_for_puppet_manifests) of the [Fuel wiki](https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Fuel). ## Testing ---------- Testing is important for the fuel-library to ensure changes do what they are supposed to do, regressions are not introduced and all code is of the highest quality. The fuel-library leverages existing Puppet module rspec tests, [bats](https://github.com/sstephenson/bats) tests for bash scripts and noop tests for testing the module deployment tasks in fuel-library. ### Puppet module tests TODO. ### Bats: Bash Automated Testing System TODO. ### fuel-library noop TODO.
deleted_lines: # Fuel is the Ultimate Do-it-Yourself Kit for OpenStack # Purpose built to assimilate the hard-won experience of our services team, it contains the tooling, information, and support you need to accelerate time to production with OpenStack cloud. OpenStack is a very versatile and flexible cloud management platform. By exposing its portfolio of cloud infrastructure services – compute, storage, networking and other core resources — through ReST APIs, it enables a wide range of control over these services, both from the perspective of an integrated Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) controlled by applications, as well as automated manipulation of the infrastructure itself. This architectural flexibility doesn’t set itself up magically; it asks you, the user and cloud administrator, to organize and manage a large array of configuration options. Consequently, getting the most out of your OpenStack cloud over time – in terms of flexibility, scalability, and manageability – requires a thoughtful combination of automation and configuration choices. Mirantis Fuel for OpenStack was created to solve exactly this problem.

commit_message:
Use the testr from os-testr env

The functional tests have site-packages set to true for the tox
environment to make some of the live tests work correctly. In the
recent past this has meant that testr is now no longer available in
.tox/py27-gate/bin. Instead we used one that we know will be there.

Change-Id: I77befff673f46de85510d60cc4faf1c85d36086d

added_lines: .. _login-murano-instance: .. toctree:: :maxdepth: 2: ======================== Login to murano instance ======================== After application deployment successfully completed, application becomes available for the user. Sometimes, it's needed to go to the virtual machine with the installed application. Let's see how it can be done. All cloud images (including images, imported from `application catalog <http://apps.openstack.org/>`_) has authentication by password turned off. That's why login from horizon console is not possible. So ssh is used to reach an instance spawned by murano. Possible default image users are the following: * *ec2-user* * *ubuntu* or *debian* (depending on the OS) To be able to login by ssh, key pair is required. It can be provided during application creation: .. image:: figures/add_key_pair.png :alt: Application creation: key pair :width: 630 px If you don't have one, you can do it directly from application form, by pressing plus sign. After deployment is completed, need to find out instance IP address. Check out: * Deployment logs .. image:: figures/app_logs.png :alt: Application logs: IP is provided :width: 630 px * Instance detailed parameters. Link is available in application details page .. image:: figures/app_details.png :alt: Application details: instance details link :width: 630 px Execute the following command: .. code-block:: console $ ssh ec2user@<IP> -i <key.location>

commit_message:
Add DnsServers param to network config templates

This patch adds a new optional DnsServers parameter
which can be used to provide a custom list of DNS
resolvers which will be configured in resolv.conf.

Change-Id: I2bb7259ebc09d786dc56da18694c862f802091b1
Depends-On: I9edecfdd4e1d0f39883b72be554cd92c5685881d

added_lines: DnsServers: # Override this via parameter_defaults default: [] description: A list of DNS servers (2 max for some implementations) that will be added to resolv.conf. type: json dns_servers: {get_param: DnsServers}

commit_message:
Spec for TripleO overcloud deployment library

Change-Id: I60ea08fdd10c88e64b56b196555e5e708da3ff3d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/54/219754/19 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================================ Library support for TripleO Overcloud Deployment ================================================ We need a TripleO library that supports the overcloud deployment workflow. Problem Description =================== With Tuskar insufficient for complex overcloud deployments, TripleO has moved to an overcloud deployment workflow that bypasses Tuskar. This workflow can be summarized as follows: * The user edits the templates and environment file. These can be stored anywhere. * Templates may be validated by Heat. * Templates and environment are sent to Heat for overcloud deployment. * Post-deploy, overcloud endpoints are configured. This workflow is already supported by the CLI. However, from a UI perspective, although the workflow is straightforward, it is not simple. Here are some of the complications that arise: * Some of the business logic in this workflow is not currently supported by a REST API, makiing it difficult for a UI to duplicate - especially if that UI is not Python-based. * If the TripleO overcloud deployment workflow changes, it is easy for the CLI and UI approach to end up on divergent paths - a dangerous situation. * The CLI approach allows open-ended flexibility (the CLI doesn't care where the templates come from) that is detrimental for a UI (the UI user doesn't care where the templates are stored, but consistency in approach is desirable to prevent divergence among UIs). There is a need to create common code that accomodates the flexibility of the CLI with the ease-of-use needs of UI consumers. Proposed Change =============== In order to solve this problem, we propose the following: * Encapsulate the business logic involved in the overcloud deploy workflow within the tripleo-common library. * Provide a simplified workflow to hide unneeded complexity from UI consumers - for example, template storage. * Create a TripleO REST API with CORS support to allow UIs to easily access this workflow logic. * Update the CLI to use these APIs to prevent divergence with UIs. The first two points deserve further explanation. First, let us lay out the proposed UI workflow: * A deployment plan is initially created by pushing the entire tripleo-heat-template tree into a data store. * The user specifies deployment options given by Heat template capabilities. This results in an updated resource registry in an environment file saved to the data store. * Now that the deployment options are specified, the user can configure deployment parameters given by Heat. Edited parameters are updated and an updated environment file is saved to the data store. 'Roles' no longer exist as an independently modeled concept, but can still be derived from available Heat parameters. * With configuration complete, the user triggers the deployment of the overcloud. The templates and environment file are taken from the data store and sent to Heat. * Once overcloud deployment is complete, the overcloud endpoints are initialized. In order to fulfill this workflow, we propose to promote the use of Swift as the template data store. If a UI wishes to allow users to edit these templates (and store versions in, say, git), they can still do so; however it is up to the UI to ensure that these templates end up in the correct location in Swift. The tripleo-common library functions needed are: * **Plan Creation** * **create_plan(plan_name, templates)**: Creates a plan by creating a Swift container matching plan_name, and placing the tripleo-heat-templates and an environment file into it. * **Deployment Options** * **get_deployment_options(plan_name)**: Determine available deployment options by retrieving plan_name's templates from Swift and using the proposed Heat resource-capabilities API (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/196656/7/specs/liberty/resource-capabilities.rst). * **update_deployment_options(plan_name, deployment_options)**: Retrieve plan_name's environment file from Swift and update the resource_registry tree according to the values passed in by deployment_options. Then update the environment file in Swift. * **Deployment Configuration** * **get_deployment_parameters(plan_name)**: Determine available deployment parameters by retrieving plan_name's templates from Swift and using the proposed Heat nested-validation API call (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/197199/5/specs/liberty/nested-validation.rst). * **update_deployment_parameters(plan_name, deployment_parameters)**: Retrieve plan_name's environment file from Swift and update the parameters according to the values passed in by deployment_parameters. Then update the environment file in Swift. * **get_deployment_roles(plan_name)**: Determine available deployment roles by retrieving plan_name's deployment parameters and deriving available roles from parameter names. * **Deployment** * **deploy_plan(plan_name)**: Retrieve plan_name's templates and environment file from Swift and use them in a Heat API call to create the overcloud stack. Perform any needed pre-processing of the template. * **Post-Deploy** * **postdeploy_plan(plan_name)**: Initialize the API endpoints of the overcloud corresponding to plan_name. Alternatives ------------ An alternative is to accept the TripleO refrain: "The OpenStack APIs are our APIs". This means that UIs should, in theory, be able to duplicate overcloud deployment simply by using available OpenStack API calls. In practice this has proven not to be case, resulting in UIs lagging behind CLI deployment capabilities. In addition the usage of OpenStack APIs has proven to be highly specific. TripleO may be far more appealing if it shields this inner-complexity in favor of presenting end users with a simplified interface. Security Impact --------------- None, as we are simply increasing the exposure of the business logic that TripleO already uses. Other End User Impact --------------------- End users would find it far easier to adapt the TripleO method of deployment. This may result in increased usage. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- Right now, changing the overcloud deployment workflow results in stress resulting from the need to individually update both the CLI and UI code. Converging the two makes this a far easier proposition. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignees: * tzumainn * akrivoka * jtomasek * dmatthews Work Items ---------- The work items required are: * Develop the tripleo-common library to provide the functionality described above. * Create a corresponding TripleO REST API. * Update the CLI to use the new API. * Add the appropriate tests to the TripleO CI. Dependencies ============ We are dependent upon two HEAT specs: * Heat resource-capabilities API (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/196656/7/specs/liberty/resource-capabilities.rst) * Heat nested-validation API (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/197199/5/specs/liberty/nested-validation.rst) Testing ======= The TripleO CI should be updated to test the new API. Documentation Impact ==================== The new REST API will have to be well-documented and meet OpenStack standards. References ==========

commit_message:
Add multithreading to url_available check

* Checks are performed in parallel.
* Puppet exception is raised after the first failure.
* Add unit test.

Change-Id: Ie09930d63198ff2bcd3f1b0ed4a94ec4b8a59fd6
Closes-Bug: #1457190
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/95/225095/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: threads_count = 16 Thread.abort_on_exception=true request = Net::HTTP::Head.new(u.request_uri) # within a thread pool equal to threads_count url.each_slice(threads_count) do |group| threads = [] group.each do |u| threads << Thread.new do fetch(u, http_proxy) end end threads.each(&:join)
deleted_lines: request = Net::HTTP::Get.new(u.request_uri) url.each do |u| fetch(u, http_proxy)

subject: Number of yaql functions caused AmbiguousFunctionException
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-01 12:28:08.000000000', 'files': ['murano/tests/unit/dsl/meta/TestEngineFunctions.yaml', 'murano/dsl/yaql_integration.py', 'murano/tests/unit/dsl/test_engine_yaql_functions.py', 'murano/tests/unit/dsl/meta/DerivedFrom2Classes.yaml', 'murano/dsl/yaql_functions.py', 'murano/tests/unit/dsl/meta/SingleInheritanceChild.yaml', 'murano/tests/unit/dsl/test_multiple_inheritance.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano/commit/c4f1f14692ac07dd56aa32575d385ec711f440d8', 'message': 'Number of yaql functions caused AmbiguousFunctionException

There are several commonly used MuranoPL-specific yaql functions
that were extension methods (i.e. those that can be called as both as functions
(foo($x)) and as methods ($x.foo())) before Murano switched to yaql 1.0
(because this was the only option for yaql 0.2). To keep backward compatibility
they remain such after migration to 1.0 but only for MuranoPL/1.0 format.
The new approach was to make them pure functions and auto convert to
extension methods for MuranoPL/1.0. However due to error both original
and auto-generated versions of the same functions were placed in the same
yaql context. As a result when attempts to call them as a functions
(say id($this)) caused AmbiguousFunctionException to be thrown because
both function versions would satisfy this syntax.

Change-Id: Ib58c64b999a309e51a7d4a86f5de4cdce84a86d6
Closes-Bug: #1501367
(cherry picked from commit c3aa79590890882dfa4b561f5c50bc03f6a66978)
'}]
commit_message:
Number of yaql functions caused AmbiguousFunctionException

There are several commonly used MuranoPL-specific yaql functions
that were extension methods (i.e. those that can be called as both as functions
(foo($x)) and as methods ($x.foo())) before Murano switched to yaql 1.0
(because this was the only option for yaql 0.2). To keep backward compatibility
they remain such after migration to 1.0 but only for MuranoPL/1.0 format.
The new approach was to make them pure functions and auto convert to
extension methods for MuranoPL/1.0. However due to error both original
and auto-generated versions of the same functions were placed in the same
yaql context. As a result when attempts to call them as a functions
(say id($this)) caused AmbiguousFunctionException to be thrown because
both function versions would satisfy this syntax.

Change-Id: Ib58c64b999a309e51a7d4a86f5de4cdce84a86d6
Closes-Bug: #1501367
(cherry picked from commit c3aa79590890882dfa4b561f5c50bc03f6a66978)

commit_message:
Fixed YAQL tag leakage to YAML loader

This is the same fix as in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/199109/
This code was copied to python-muranoclient from murano but was
fixed then only in one place. Despite the bug exist for many releases
it didn't affected murano until recent changes to HOT translator
(or at least it was never reported)

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/199109/ commit message
for more details

Change-Id: I910f4117050430433fd9fdd291f0ba9659f75825
Closes-Bug: #1501570
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-muranoclient refs/changes/05/229705/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: yaml.add_constructor(u'!yaql', yaql_constructor, YaqlYamlLoader) yaml.add_implicit_resolver(u'!yaql', YaqlExpression, Loader=YaqlYamlLoader)

subject: Remove early yields in _iter_hosts in dhcp agent
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-24 16:51:55.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/fc1c812fa6f6fab1910f00f23cb4efe45793557a', 'message': "Remove early yields in _iter_hosts in dhcp agent

There were early yields in the DHCP agent to handling skipping
lease setup for certain IPv6 addresses. However, the setup for
name resolution in _output_addn_hosts_file depends on the same
function so certain IPv6 addresses weren't getting name resolution.

This patch adjusts the function to return a flag indicating that
DHCP isn't required for the port so the callers setting up reservations
can skip based on that and the name resolution setup can continue
as normal.

Conflicts:
	neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py
	neutron/tests/unit/agent/linux/test_dhcp.py

Change-Id: I81b4669eadaa9119e08c6a5e1d2a7b5959babdcc
Closes-Bug: #1498665
(cherry picked from commit 1daf945f832716b98b8c2d630cd2e730178a46fa)
"}]
commit_message:
Remove early yields in _iter_hosts in dhcp agent

There were early yields in the DHCP agent to handling skipping
lease setup for certain IPv6 addresses. However, the setup for
name resolution in _output_addn_hosts_file depends on the same
function so certain IPv6 addresses weren't getting name resolution.

This patch adjusts the function to return a flag indicating that
DHCP isn't required for the port so the callers setting up reservations
can skip based on that and the name resolution setup can continue
as normal.

Conflicts:
	neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py
	neutron/tests/unit/agent/linux/test_dhcp.py

Change-Id: I81b4669eadaa9119e08c6a5e1d2a7b5959babdcc
Closes-Bug: #1498665
(cherry picked from commit 1daf945f832716b98b8c2d630cd2e730178a46fa)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/24/227424/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: no_dhcp, # A flag indicating that the address doesn't need DHCP. no_dhcp = False no_dhcp = addr_mode in (constants.IPV6_SLAAC, constants.DHCPV6_STATELESS) yield (port, alloc, hostname, fqdn, no_dhcp) for (port, alloc, hostname, name, no_dhcp) in self._iter_hosts(): # don't write ip address which belongs to a dhcp disabled subnet # or an IPv6 SLAAC/stateless subnet if no_dhcp or alloc.subnet_id not in dhcp_enabled_subnet_ids: for (port, alloc, hostname, name, no_dhcp) in self._iter_hosts(): if no_dhcp: for (port, alloc, hostname, fqdn, no_dhcp) in self._iter_hosts():

commit_message:
Make chown rootwrap filter ipsec.secrets file specific

The LibreSwan ipsec driver needs to be able to change the ownership of
generated ipsec.secrets files to root. This modifies the existing
rootwrap filter to allow chown operations only to be performed on files
named ipsec.secrets that have the expected UID.

Change-Id: I1305f9e78eb5fe718f3065e6a9e690293f1fca1d
Related-bug: #1493492
(cherry picked from commit d04e5527d97433794a634510fd2f04ee6b579667)

commit_message:
Set owner to root for ipsec.secrets for LibreSwan

LibreSwan runs as root and needs access to ipsec.secrets. Currently,
ipsec.secrets is not owned by root and has 0600 permissions. This patch
adds a rootwrap filter for the chown operation and sets the
ipsec.secrets ownership to root.

Conflicts:
	neutron_vpnaas/tests/unit/services/vpn/device_drivers/test_ipsec.py

Closes-Bug: #1493492
(cherry picked from commit fed1a9b92778df4e65bbe03976573d2c82f94163)
Change-Id: I414b5d9285d7a3ba9d3132bce9d7d5e3af43c37f

commit_message:
Use right way to skip fuelmenu

Use virtualbox built-in keyboardputscancode instead of using
ssh to master node and kill fuelmenu.

commit_message:
Run the token_cleanup only in bootstrap node

Token cleanup is a cron job and now it is scheduled to
run in controller node. If there are more than one controller
node then, the cron job will be running at the same time in
all the nodes.Since cleanup involes sql select  and delete
each node will be getitng both read lock and exclusive lock.If
one node takes the lock and if the delete takes long, other
nodes are failing with oslo.db retry transaction message.

Basically running the job in all the nodes makes the whole
thing take more time. We do see exceptions in the nodes and
the token cleanup process is aborted in other nodes.

Change-Id: Ibc7ffd850073aba86217e2be5d9459bef0f87860
Closes-Bug: #1402795
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/82/141882/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix publish_exists_event authentication exception

The nova client created by create_nova_admin_client was throwing
an Authentication exception. In order to properly create this client,
novaclient needs tenant_id set to a tenant-id. Note: novaclient
documents that project-id is specifically a tenant-name and from
what I can tell it isn't required for Trove use-cases.

Added a unit test to check that create_nova_admin_client causes
a nova client to get instantiated with the correct params.

Change-Id: I34d7d9dd36117bff796db22b851656ba78988558
Closes-bug: 1473550

commit_message:
Automatically install packages when upgrading

This simplifies use of tripleo::packages so that when
enable_upgrade is set to true you no longer have to enable_install
as well.

commit_message:
Add a --template option for custom HTML templates

Adds a custom -t (--template) option that can be used
to specify a custom HTML template. This option can
be useful if you want to embed the output of
reviewday into a non-openstack themed page.

Change-Id: Ia1ca8b093c934e442f1c3bbdd79c700713818ba9

Use doc8 style checker

files conform to certain requirements, as documented at

commit_message:
Improve error message for create QoS Spec

When input a "QoS Spec" name that already exists in create
"QoS Spec" modal form, we will see the error message:
"Unable to create QoS Spec" in the top right corner of the
page, this error message is not specific and clear. If we
provide specific and clear error message: 'QoS Spec name "%s"
already exists.' beside the name field, it will be more better.

Change-Id: Iff762e9570f656df50e9b84d7f54acb5b9c955d7
Closes-Bug: #1494166

commit_message:
ifcfg: Add support for dns_servers

Adds in the ability to optionally configure DNS
server settings via the ifcfg file formats.
The dns_servers JSON is an array which currently
supports either 1 or 2 DNS servers (per limitations
of the ifcfg format).

Change-Id: I9edecfdd4e1d0f39883b72be554cd92c5685881d

subject: Handle OS_CLOUD and OS_REGION_NAME friendly-like
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-30 21:29:30.000000000', 'files': ['os_client_config/config.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-client-config/commit/723b893f22fc3db74761dc64e5296360e5739147', 'message': "Handle OS_CLOUD and OS_REGION_NAME friendly-like

If you're using os-client-config and ansible and python-openstackclient,
the envvar override support can get tricky if you've set OS_CLOUD to
select a cloud for python-openstackclient, leading you to have an empty
cloud called envvars when you were not actually trying to create one.

Special-case pull both out, treating OS_CLOUD as a default value for
get_one_cloud() and only creating an envvars cloud if OS_REGION_NAME is
not the only env var provided.

Change-Id: I2a5235c18f9be1e5dfc019888a0c187ef40074bc
"}]
commit_message:
Handle OS_CLOUD and OS_REGION_NAME friendly-like

If you're using os-client-config and ansible and python-openstackclient,
the envvar override support can get tricky if you've set OS_CLOUD to
select a cloud for python-openstackclient, leading you to have an empty
cloud called envvars when you were not actually trying to create one.

Special-case pull both out, treating OS_CLOUD as a default value for
get_one_cloud() and only creating an envvars cloud if OS_REGION_NAME is
not the only env var provided.

Change-Id: I2a5235c18f9be1e5dfc019888a0c187ef40074bc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-client-config refs/changes/36/229636/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # If the only environ key is region name, don't make a cloud, because # it's being used as a cloud selector if not environkeys or ( len(environkeys) == 1 and 'OS_REGION_NAME' in environkeys): # Pull out OS_CLOUD so that if it's the only thing set, do not # make an envvars cloud self.default_cloud = os.environ.pop('OS_CLOUD', None) if cloud is None and self.default_cloud: cloud = self.default_cloud

Convert cli arguments to unicode objects

This eliminates problem when non-ascii chars in plugin path led to
encoding related errors in the build operation

commit_message:
Can't create shares on drivers that don't support snapshots

For a driver that doesn't support snapshots, a share type with
snapshot_support = '<is> False' will prevent share creation.
Root cause is code in HostManager that improperly checks whether
snapshot_support (and other boolean properties) is set on each
pool. This commit fixes the check for the boolean pool capabilities.

Change-Id: I6a488788926cca119498b3de992beec3b0545259
Closes-Bug: #1498646
(cherry picked from commit 8a34fb3890810330a9b8a2d659739d92134a832c)

commit_message:
Tests requirements and goals

Change-Id: I15d36d0af2123d4ac0d99d7167df03e5797b6350
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-specs refs/changes/80/180180/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================== Puppet openstack tests: requirements and goals ============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/puppet-openstack/+spec/tests-requirements-and-goals This Blueprint proposes to establish requirements and goals for beaker-rspec tests in all puppet-openstack modules Problem description =================== A brief survey in downstream, showed some recurring pattern when dealing with bugs from puppet modules: - a change in a common dependency (usually concat) - idempotency not respected - backwards incompatibility - internal parameters position inconsinstency - out of scope modification (e.g. ssh configuration modified in swift module) Functional and integration tests should be added to upcoming beaker-rspec framework to identify these common issues before merging a patch. Proposed change =============== Beaker-rspec basic module test are almost in place. Other serverspec test should be added to address above scenarios. - A test to detect changes in dependency. Should call a reasonable amount of classes that use dependencies as much as possible. - A test for idempotency. Should be simple, reapply the same generic manifest three times and check for errors - To detect backwards incompatibility it may be useful to launch a first round of test using test from unchanged version - To detect parameters inconsinstency in ini files, it could be useful to check if configuration parameters are created exactly where expected. - Detecting out of scope modification may be challenging. A test should define a scope, then track all the modifications done, and notifies all unrecognized ones Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None Module API impact ----------------- None End user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Increased time for change verification during review. Deployer impact --------------------- Set of test should be transparent to the deployer. Developer impact ---------------- Developers will need to add tests to fullfill the testing requirements and cover most of the scenarios Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: EmilienM Other contributors: nibalizer Work Items ---------- In order of importance: * finish basic structures & basic tests: - clone modules and test dependencies - compile catalog with all classes - fix orchestrations issues - ensure idempotency - basic serverspec, (e.g. nestat/API) * backwards compatibility * Test on other distribution. - more scenarios, more coverage, more serverspec - stabilization, documentation, adoption * parameter inconsinstency * out of scope modifications * Integration with tempest Dependencies ============ https://review.openstack.org/#/q/topic:bug-1444736,n,z beaker-rspec Testing ======= This spec is about testing. See other sections Documentation Impact ==================== A Document should be created with guidelines on type of test to provide with every change. References ========== https://github.com/puppetlabs/beaker/wiki/How-to-Write-a-Beaker-Test-for-a-Module https://github.com/puppetlabs/beaker/wiki/Creating-A-Test-Environment

commit_message:
Update neutron quota update parameters

Add 5 parameters:
  vip, pool, member, health_monitor, rbac_policy
(df) Edits for clarity, plus fixed typos in unrelated file.

Change-Id: I4096af3ce82936d19dd611910f2cd2b71dfbb8fd
Closes-Bug: #1406957

commit_message:
Rename 'volutils' attribute in iSCSI initiator unit tests

This patch renames the instances of the iSCSI initiator utils
classes in the according unit tests in order to remain consistent.

This was missed in I1bc6628dc842595de3fb6daa4f39ca330609cfa2.

commit_message:
Always send volume_id when booting with legacy bdm

Commit 5153dcda807c554769081626c10c43d16adea671 removed bdm v2-only
request parameters to pass nova api v2.1 schema validation, but also
removed the ability to boot with legacy bdm specifying volume_id only.

This adds volume_id back to the request for legacy bdm when
no other parameters are specified.

Closes-Bug: #1501435

Conflicts:
	novaclient/tests/functional/test_servers.py

Change-Id: Ie8c56c28492793990ef7ed6dc54768cef9e28a98
(cherry picked from commit abd0630badaff18ca998db2feccb058e8ee75f23)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/26/229826/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _boot_server_with_legacy_bdm(self, bdm_params=()): bdm_params = ':'.join(bdm_params) if bdm_params: bdm_params = ''.join((':', bdm_params)) "--block-device-mapping vda=%(volume_id)s%(bdm_params)s" % { "volume_id": volume.id, "bdm_params": bdm_params})) def test_boot_server_with_legacy_bdm(self): # bdm v1 format # <id>:<type>:<size(GB)>:<delete-on-terminate> # params = (type, size, delete-on-terminate) params = ('', '', '1') self._boot_server_with_legacy_bdm(bdm_params=params) def test_boot_server_with_legacy_bdm_volume_id_only(self): self._boot_server_with_legacy_bdm()

commit_message:
Make __all__ immutable

The point of __all__ is to make static analysis more reliable. Using a
mutable type allows that goal to be circumvented at runtime. Tuples are
immutable.

Change-Id: I88d7459b33471efca8f2599e379665010403341c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/56/229656/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: __all__ = ('Server', 'httplib', 'subprocess')

commit_message:
Preparing new plugin version

Modify the setup.py and setup.cfg (no pbr here) to prepare the
2014.2.3.1.1 version.

It stands for:

  * 2014.2.3 (Neutron Juno bugfix 3 version)
  * + 1.1 (MidoNet plugin bugfix 1 version)

added_lines: Step 1: Read the OpenStack Style Commandments http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/ Step 2: Read on Commit Messages --------------- The common OpenStack guideline related to commit messages can be found at http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#commit-messages Further guidance contains additional agreements which are specific to the Murano Application repository. Message title should be started with the name of the particular application enclosed in brackets which relates to this change. In the case when application relates to some group of the applications which have a separate folder in the repository than directory name may be added before application name. Instead of:: Change initial value of mysql username to root you should write:: [MySQL] Change initial value of mysql username to root In case application belongs to some group and located in the subfolder then you can use group name as a prefix:: [Windows][ActiveDirectory] Default recovery password removed If it is initial commit for an application then the title should be:: [Docker][Elasticsearch] Application added If case commit does not related to any application then prefix should not be used.

deleted_lines: What is this file? ================== This file is a loosely-organized list of some of the high-level and long-term goals of the project's core development team. It is *not* a list of specific tasks or ongoing work - for that, please see the list of blueprints targeted to the current release cycle, here: https://launchpad.net/ironic/ Some of the Big Things we're working on ======================================= * Implementing a formal model for Node states. * Node introspection (discover properties of a known Node) See https://github.com/stackforge/ironic-discoverd * Support RAID and firmware management * Improving the Agent deploy driver so that we can deprecate the current "pxe" driver (which is really pxe-boot + iscsi-deploy).

commit_message:
Put py34 first in the env order of tox

To solve the problem of "db type could not be determined" on py34 we
have to run first the py34 env to, then, run py27.  This patch puts py34
first on the tox.ini list of envs to avoid this problem to happen.

Change-Id: I80b755d0aa18db7c55ccaecd1c4f64d4fe09b4c5
Closes-Bug: #1489059
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-lib refs/changes/16/229616/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py34,py27,pep8

commit_message:
Compute API os-services v2.1 needs update

New flag to be visible in service response:
GET /v2.1/{tenant_id}/os-services response needs to have new attribute: forced_down
GET /v2.1/{tenant_id}/os-services/detail response needs to have new attribute: forced_down
New API needs to be added:
PUT /v2.1/{tenant_id}/os-services/force-down

(df) Added descriptions of request and response parameters.
Updated general description for the API.
Fixed typo in unrelated (telemetry) file after doing a spell-check.

Change-Id: I157015e12862d3b3f1014ac9748ef2b6bf4ee386
Closes-bug: #1499281

commit_message:
Add Shared File Systems API v1,v2 sections

Added the documentation of the core APIs of the
Shared File Systems [1] API v1 and v2.

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Manila

commit_message:
Revert netapp_lib dependency in NetApp cDOT Manila drivers

The community asked us to remove the dependency on a PyPI
library with a proprietary license.  This commit does that
while preserving some minor refactoring that was done at the
same time.

Reverts commit ca6168d01bea405718bbf6a36d4bb75c23d1b783.

Closes-Bug: #1499334
Change-Id: I1a4b1b2b2151bb222ae5c77b9b317e7505255067
(cherry picked from commit f925c049007fbd5ec71a4ec59de1120d35ad66af)

commit_message:
Return missing authtoken options

Example configs were missing keystone_authtoken section after moving
to generated config files. This change returns that to generation.

Closes-Bug: #1500361

Change-Id: I6ee82c38061d483cea7254d155d9a72436880e84
(cherry picked from commit b1d2d938d282ccd51986e57a638f8ea5bec56b0f)

commit_message:
Add service-providers API for service-type extension

  Add get /service-providers

  service type specific (Loadbalancer etc.) does not needed,
  because these are separately documented.

Change-Id: I649d4871a6f6674365dc4792f10b2888d7f83217
Closes-Bug: #1239153

added_lines: A service_provider object. A string of identify service. Valid strings are LOADBALANCER, CORE, DUMMY, LOADBALANCERV2, FIREWALL, VPN, METERING, L3_ROUTER_NAT, FLAVORS, and QOS An option, if specified, the provider becomes default for given service type. User-facing representation of the provider. '>

commit_message:
Remove discover

The discover package is not needed since we use testtools which
uses unittest2 which includes discover internally.

You might think discover is needed for python26 but it's not.

Change-Id: I4014a13c5cb19c36b492165e45a05d164e422a09

commit_message:
Move tune2fs calls into priv_ops

Rather than calling utils.execute('tune2fs'..., run_as_root=True)
directly, call a function in priv_ops.

Change-Id: I379210a083c7db1ebd6183be7408393ad69d4283

commit_message:
Move kpartx privileged calls to module

A new module is created to contain privileged calls. As an
example, it contains functions for calling kpartx, then the
callers are changed to use it.

Change-Id: Iedc8703f5baaf7b5ad96483d9021ef17c8e151b6

commit_message:
Adds RetryDecorator for modify_virt_resource

jobutils' modify_virt_resource can fail while setting up the
VM's serial port connection. This can cause random failures while
running tempest. Retrying the operation will yield success.

Adds oslo.service as a dependency in requirements.txt

Closes-Bug: #1501522

Change-Id: I4c8ad517c0893f1e4e2a59f64402aad159015f5e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-win refs/changes/61/229661/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Test hot package files with sets instead of lists

Before test_hot_package file used lists for testing which files were
generated. This could potentially lead to false negatives, as os.walk
returns file names in arbitrary order.
This commit replaces lists with sets to mitigate the problem.
Renames _build_hot_resources_dict as it does not return a dict.

Change-Id: I348d5c5bbf0db0d4d734d07a5449e6f3d171fcbf
Closes-Bug: #1494722

commit_message:
Test hot package files with sets instead of lists

Before test_hot_package file used lists for testing which files were
generated. This could potentially lead to false negatives, as os.walk
returns file names in arbitrary order.
This commit replaces lists with sets to mitigate the problem.
Renames _build_hot_resources_dict as it does not return a dict.

Change-Id: I348d5c5bbf0db0d4d734d07a5449e6f3d171fcbf
Closes-Bug: #1494722
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/29/229829/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: expected_result = { } self.assertSetEqual(expected_result, set(files), msg) msg = "heat files were not generated correctly. Expected empty list" self.assertEqual([], files, msg)
deleted_lines: expected_result = [ ] self.assertEqual(expected_result, files, msg) msg = "heat files were not generated correctly. Expected empty dict" self.assertEqual(files, [], msg)

commit_message:
Add diskimage-builder lint job

Add a "dib" tox environment to run "dib-lint", the linting tool
diskimage-builder runs over its included elements.

Add this as a non-voting job for now; there are issues in dib-lint and
our elements to sort out
(e.g. Ibba1dadb9e819f94294c9d583b83ff698252f93f, as a start).

Change-Id: I28459a9bbaaa6175d03dbe753498849a75942538

that were extension methods (i.e. those that can be called as both as functions
(foo($x)) and as methods ($x.foo())) before Murano switched to yaql 1.0
(because this was the only option for yaql 0.2). To keep backward compatibility
they remain such after migration to 1.0 but only for MuranoPL/1.0 format.
The new approach was to make them pure functions and auto convert to

yaql context. As a result when attempts to call them as a functions

commit_message:
Number of yaql functions caused AmbiguousFunctionException

There are several commonly used MuranoPL-specific yaql functions
that were extension methods (i.e. those that can be called as both as functions
(foo($x)) and as methods ($x.foo())) before Murano switched to yaql 1.0
(because this was the only option for yaql 0.2). To keep backward compatibility
they remain such after migration to 1.0 but only for MuranoPL/1.0 format.
The new approach was to make them pure functions and auto convert to
extension methods for MuranoPL/1.0. However due to error both original
and auto-generated versions of the same functions were placed in the same
yaql context. As a result when attempts to call them as a functions
(say id($this)) caused AmbiguousFunctionException to be thrown because
both function versions would satisfy this syntax.

Change-Id: Ib58c64b999a309e51a7d4a86f5de4cdce84a86d6
Closes-Bug: #1501367

commit_message:
Skip caching for dnf (Fedora 22) builds

We are still working on the caching story for dnf-based builds
(i.e. Fedora 22). There are a couple of options which we will work
through on the linked page.  We will sort this out before we move the
devstack job (yet to be created, because the nodes aren't there yet)
out of experimental.

In the mean time, disable the caching in these elements so we can get
Fedora 22 image builds (currently they're in a big looping failure
[1]).

[1] http://nodepool.openstack.org/image.log

Change-Id: I3a435889fc5109d7365240068047aac98abc605e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/28/229728/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Fix setting of "snapshot_support" extra spec for tempest
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-23 10:58:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/9c224a42c2fa56c60b9a316625411496f262a3ec', 'message': 'Fix setting of "snapshot_support" extra spec for tempest

Tempest test module "test_shares_actions.py" uses custom share_type,
but do not allow to redefine extra spec "snapshot_support".

commit_message:
Fix setting of "snapshot_support" extra spec for tempest

Tempest test module "test_shares_actions.py" uses custom share_type,
but do not allow to redefine extra spec "snapshot_support".
And fails for drivers that do not have snapshot support and report
such capability as "False".

Changes:
- Add new config option called "capability_snapshot_support" that
will be used for each share type created in Tempest by default.
- Make it default to existing config option "run_snapshot_tests"
as they will be equal in most cases. But separate their logic, as
we may want just to disable snapshot tests running tempest locally
and testing some other feature having snapshot support in back end.
- Rename existing config option "storage_protocol" to
"capability_storage_protocol" for consistency with new option. And
keep old name as "deprecated".

Change-Id: I9ba0a9b10ffc3f0fda6094a3f5cad26a2e8a447f
Closes-Bug: #1498858

commit_message:
Fix deletion of error state access rules

Deny access to share instance in case access rule is in error state
and has access to share instances.

Add function 'share_instance_access_get_all' to DB API to check if we can
delete share access or need to remove access to share instance at first.

Closes-bug: #1495892

Change-Id: Id1f138e6bb48daca0a768dea7440829185fca9e5

commit_message:
Make MySQL ignore lost+found directory in its datadir

This commit introduces optional ignore_db_dirs parameter that can be passed to
mysql::server. It is expected to be an array and is empty by default.

Change-Id: Ic8815b89fea41182692f9f8fafd07bbe6ca15af6
Closes-Bug: 1484552

commit_message:
Use stable/liberty ironic-inspector for func tests on stable/liberty

We probably don't want stable to get broken by some refactoring
in inspector master.

Change-Id: I7a2ab142429699b6d96acb1f68bce6af0805c3d0
